newsitem.title: CHINA: Versace murder dismays Asia's fashion trade.
newsitem.headline: Versace murder dismays Asia's fashion trade.

text.p: The murder of fashion designer Gianni Versace sent shockwaves through Asia on Wednesday and cast gloom over one of the biggest fashion shows in Hong Kong.
"It is a shock to the industry," said Kenneth Fang of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council (TDC), at the opening session of Hong Kong Fashion Week.
"It is a loss to the fashion industry. We are very sorry to hear the news. Actually he does have a very sizeable market in Hong Kong," said Fang, head of the TDC's apparel committee.

At the Versace flagship store in Sydney a small printed sign announced the shop was closed for trading until Thursday, and in Singapore mannequins in the designer's boutiques were dressed in black to mark his death.
In Tokyo, a Gianni Versace Japan company spokeswoman said staff were stunned but there were no plans to hold a commemoration ceremony.
"We were very shocked and saddened when we heard the news this morning. We're waiting for word from the headquarters in Italy before we do anything," she said.
The 50-year-old Italian fashion designer was shot twice on the steps of his Miami Beach mansion by a lone gunman on Tuesday.
A spokeswoman for the five Gianni Versace boutiques in Hong Kong, where brand name snobbery reigns, said more people than usual visited the boutiques on Wednesday.

"Today we have had a larger flow of people in the shops because some of Mr Versace's long-term fans came to chat with us and take a look at the clothes after they heard the news," the spokeswoman said.
"Some people may have wanted to collect particular items," she said.
Hong Kong designers were shattered by his death and paid tribute to his talent.

"I feel very sad," Kevin Yeung, chairman of the Hong Kong Designers' Association, told Reuters. "It's a great pity. He was very talented. I was very shocked that such violence should have taken place when he was in such an advanced country."
The sentiment was echoed by Ika, an Indonesian Chinese designer based in Hong Kong.

"I was very, very saddened, very shocked because he is one of my very favourite designers," said Ika. "And I am sure that he's going to be missed, not only by customers ... (but by) all the people who love fashion," she said.
Model Karin Holm said she was puzzled by the murder.
"I was shocked because I didn't know his life was in danger, I couldn't see any reason for him to get killed or deserve that fate at all. Personally I think Versace is one of the greatest tailors."
Socialite and businesswoman Jennifer Tose, who wears Versace designs, said she was stunned by his death and expected his creations to become collectibles.
"The first thing I said was 'Oh, my God'," she sighed. "I wear Versace clothes myself. I feel it's a pity. Even if he has successors, the clothes won't be the same."
"I think now his work will become collectible items."
In Sydney's busy lunchtime traffic, most passers-by only threw a quick glance at the Versace shopfront sign but some of the designer's fans stopped to remember him.
"It's really sad that with all the violence in the world you can't even stand around outside your house. He should have stayed in Italy," said 22-year-old Gemma Colomeo, a former fashion student.
Sales staff at Versace's Singapore store said it was appropriate to change the colour scheme of the store to black to mark his death.
"The entire Versace line across the world is saddened by the death. In Singapore we are donning black attire on all our mannequins," a spokesman for the Versace store said.
Asked if there had been any change in store sales after news of the designer's murder, he said it was business as usual.
"The line will still sell well if not even better after his death ... we are confident his fashion empire will continue," the spokesman said.
In Tokyo, Jun Ashida, famed clothes designer for many of Japan's Imperial Family members, said Versace's talents were irreplaceable.

"Nobody can replace someone with the talents that he had. It's truly a big loss for the fashion world. He was a trendsetter and a pioneer. In that sense the fashion world will lose some of its vigour."
Versace shopper Chizuru Yoshimura, 28, said the designer's death would have an impact on fashion in Japan.
"He was one of the major designers so I think the fashion scene here will change quite a bit," she said.
"It's a great loss. I really liked his style even though it's really expensive," another shopper, Atsuko Shizukawa, 21, said.

In Bombay, Narendra Kumar Ahmed, fashion editor of the Indian edition of Elle magazine, said the industry had lost a distinctive style "which was glamorous, had shades of Hollywood-style glamour in its modern context".
